content.statement: mts-001-definition is a fundamental concept in Health-Sciences Medicine Surgery Vascular Pathology Venous Compression-Syndromes May-Thurner that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

explanation.intuition: Understanding mts-001-definition helps build foundational knowledge. The concept connects to broader principles in the field.
explanation.key_insight: The key aspects of mts-001-definition include core principles, common applications, and integration with related concepts.
explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of mts-001-definition.

anatomic_variants.classic: Left CIV compression by right CIA - most common (>95%)
anatomic_variants.right_sided: Right CIV compression by left CIA - rare
anatomic_variants.bilateral: Compression of both iliac veins - rare
anatomic_variants.external_iliac: Compression at external iliac level - less common

epidemiology.prevalence: Anatomic compression in 20-30% of population; symptomatic in 2-5%
epidemiology.dvt_association: 50-60% of left iliofemoral DVT have MTS anatomy

presentation.asymptomatic: Many have anatomic compression without symptoms
presentation.acute_presentation: Left iliofemoral DVT (most common presenting scenario)

diagnosis.duplex_ultrasound: May show iliac vein stenosis; limited by bowel gas
diagnosis.ct_venography: Shows compression at cross-over; may underestimate stenosis
diagnosis.ivus: Gold standard for stenosis assessment; >50% compression diagnostic
diagnosis.venography: Performed during intervention; shows collaterals, stenosis

treatment.asymptomatic: No treatment required for incidental finding without symptoms
symptomatic_without_dvt: Stenting if significant stenosis and symptoms

acute: Stenting of underlying stenosis after thrombus clearance
chronic: Consider stenting if residual stenosis and symptoms

definition.@value: Compression of left common iliac vein by right common iliac artery, predisposing to venous stenosis and left iliofemoral DVT

clinical_pearls: Left leg DVT in young woman = always think May-Thurner
50-60% of left iliofemoral DVT have underlying MTS
IVUS is gold standard for assessing compression severity
Stent the underlying stenosis AFTER clearing the thrombus, not before

citations.source: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill.
